segments.text: I said, well, the salient parts.
And I thought, gosh, well, which are the not salient parts?
All right, well, that's interesting.
And that's certainly worth discussing, isn't it?
Yeah, I mean, I understand, and I knew, you know, going into the publication of this book, that there'd be a lot of focus on J.D.
Salinger.
As you surely know as you read this book, it's a book about my whole life and a woman's whole story.
The reason why I had to tell that story is that every piece leads out of every other piece, and there was a big piece missing for a lot of women.
And actually, Salinger plays a surprisingly large role considering the relatively short period that I was with him.
I think because he was such an enormously powerful force in my life that he really passed a very long shadow for a long time.
But actually what I've been observing

among people that I'm starting to hear from, people who come to my website, I have to talk about it is that at least as much as Satan found or actually more, they're interested in, it's not me, it's the story of a woman that's interested in.
You have to acknowledge that.
Hi, good afternoon.
Hi.
Thank you.
How are you doing?
Very well.
But do you think that there would have been...
Oh, of course not.
Of course not.
I mean, I've written other books that were worthy of attention I'm unfamiliar with.
I actually believe that this story would be just as valid, if it were.
if it were the story of an 18-year-old girl with any strong, powerful man.
It intensifies the effect that this is a person
about whom I was forbidden to speak.
But I'm... Forbidden by understanding?
Oh, yes.
He never had to say that.
He never had to say that.
I mean, look, the whole world knows that.
That's certainly why so many people are so up in arms now.
J.D.
Sanger laid down the rules.
you know, 30, 40 years ago about how he was to be treated, and to an astonishing degree, the world has responded, okay, it's sort of unprecedented phenomenon, if you ask me.
To a degree, you don't mind asking?
No, of course not.
He hasn't published anything in how long?
The last published story was 1965.
So that's 33 years.
32 years.
And he was really...

I think if you want to maintain the image of an icon it helps not to be too too available because the more we see of a person the easier it is to cut them down to size and I say that as a person who about whom much has been known and so it's very easy to
to point out my flaws, because I've published thousands of words about them.
J.B.
Slander has published four books, a handful, and four extraordinary books.
You know, the Wizard of Oz knew how it went.
Go behind the curtain if you want to keep your worshippers in line.
And, you know, there's a kind of irony to the situation to me that had he made himself more accessible and available, had he spoken and conveyed
some message himself to the readers to so long to hear from him.

And my own story, well, I believe, you know, just as weirdy, it would be the same piece of writing, but it would no doubt have created a lot less of a stir than it has, because this is the first word on Salinger.
I didn't set out to, it wasn't my place to, and I didn't pretend to say,
I'm the biographer of J.D.
Salinger.
I had a very limited 12 month window of access to this man 25 years ago and that's what I
That's the only thing I can speak of with any authority.
He was midlife at that point.
He was about 52.
I'm older now than he was now, which annoyed me when I read that he was 50.
He was already older than he was.
You know, I'm thinking of my, you know, really, because he was always, to me, this older icon.
But he's 79.
And I suppose that you haven't heard anything back from him.
I think I went to see him last night.
No, and I wouldn't have expected to.
No, I'm very grateful that I had that final meeting.
I think my life would feel very different right now if I hadn't been able to look in the eye.
And I thought a lot about that.
It's interesting that he...
allowed that to happen.
He, you know, I didn't, I wasn't breaking down his hair.
He chose to come to the door.
Um, so when you went there, it was a crapshoot, as far as you could say, whether he would come or whether he would.
I never thought it was a crapshoot.
Well, it's, you know, it's life.
No.
Truthfully,
I knew he could come.
I knew he could come.
But you also think he knew it was you out there?
Well, the way it happened, I knocked at the door.
His wife was in the kitchen.
She said, what do you want?
And I said, I've come to see Jerry.
Would you tell him Joyce Maynard is here?
So she disappeared into the back room that I know well.
And she was gone a long time, 10 minutes.
He had only to stay in the bedroom.
I wasn't going to go stay.
I was going to break down the door.
But I knew he would come.
I wasn't going to make any food.
I came to speak to him.
People get to knock at people's doors.
He knocks at mine.
But I knew he would come because
All these years, Katie Salinger has been able to silence everybody.
There have been other people who have had experiences, some of them have had painful experiences, but not all of them have emerged well.
But as a person who has experienced, as a rather strong person, with no small sense of himself, who has experienced the fear of Salinger's wrath and the emotional power that he can wield,

over certainly over a young person um and when you look at that over a great many sort of you know literary highbrows who still you know bow and kneel at his feet um i i'm quite sure that he felt that if he turned to the door and told me how angry he was and that i must not do this
I would behave appropriately because I always had.
The last time he knew me, I did everything he said.
And I don't know if he's changed, but I sure have.
And I wasn't angry, you know, it wasn't a spirit of vengefulness.
You know, I've heard this quote, of course, and I sort of want to address it because I desire a person to find one angry, vengeful sentence in this book.
I went to, I know every word that I wrote, and I went to great lengths to confine myself to the telling of my story and not to the interpretation or to pass judgment.
If there are, in my story, aspects that people feel indicate a desire on my part to hurt Salinger, then I'd say what hurts Salinger is the truth about Salinger, not the facts about Salinger.
I don't offer any speculation about what's going on in his head.
What I miss in the book, what I hope was there, of course we've known it as part of as a kid,
My daughter older now than you were.
Oh, of course, that's what started me out.
But tell me what you meant.
Well, that was not what my story was.
I didn't come as a literary critic.
I didn't come as a fan.
My experience would have been hugely dishonest with me.
No, I wasn't.
some New Yorker person come to sit around and talk about Tolstoy with him.
That wasn't my story.
And I have to tell you, I don't think he would have written to me if that was who I was.
Part of what the story was is that he wasn't looking for a literary equal and intellectual companion.
That's not who he was looking for.
I think people
You know, I've been sort of well-behaved on this tour, but I'm getting a little angry, to tell you the truth, at other people who basically, as far as I can see,
want this to have been another story.
I wish that the story-wise, that when somebody finally got to be with J.D.
Salinger, he would be this wise, sagely, purer than all the rest of us person.
And they're disappointed that not just that I'm telling this story, but that the story isn't what they wanted to hear.
That there's God.
Well, it strikes me that
that the messenger of the news is being ranked, as opposed to looking at the news.
And if you say, I too, I'd love to hear what Salinger would say about writing.
I'm not angry about the news at all.
I'm just, I guess I just wish that the news, there were more news.
He didn't talk about his writing.
I wouldn't have stayed one day.
And that's not why he wanted to there, quite obviously.
He did, actually, I think you have very interesting things to say, and I think I'll record him.
about his perception of publishing, the relationship between a writer and readers.
Those are all subjects that I heard a lot about and that I remembered very well.
And about the job of a writer.
to tell the truth and to write an authentic story.
Those things we talked about, but we didn't sit around talking about great books.
But do you have a sense of why?
Do you feel that you know why he has withdrawn so eccentricly?
As I said, I don't presume to enter the hub of J.B.
Challenger and interpret him.
That would really be stepping over their mind.
And I wouldn't do that.
But just as a person who heard what he had to say about it,
He had experienced some very sharp criticism, in particular after the publication of his last story.
I don't know if you've read that story, but people didn't love it the way they loved the earlier stuff.
There had been a couple of, in particular, really brutal pieces written about it.
John Updates is one that he was very bitter about.
This is not a man.
You know, I sort of think that one of the things that
about what you do as a writer when you put your work out there.
Thank you.
I don't think writers have any obligation to give interviews, to go on book tours, to have their picture taken.
You know, I happen to do that, but I don't think that goes with the territory and you have to do that.
It may have implications for your success if you don't.
But if you don't want to do that, that's fair enough.
I've done about a thousand years.
And I'm not exaggerating the number.
Maybe a thousand author who could use it in the last 20 years.
And next month is actually the first month.
I've never missed one in 20 years in terms of interest.
Every week I've always done one.
Finally, I'm quick.
I just can't do this in the right books.
But I do think... But my point is, I have always agreed with your premise that if John Updike doesn't want to do an interview, finally I did that.
However... Or Ann Tyler, or Tony... That's great.
Fair enough.
However, if you put a book out there to be published, then one of the things that you need to, that I believe,
you need to accept is that it will receive response.
That the publication of a book involves not just the experience of the writer, but the experience of the reader.
And to shut out the reader and refuse to accept a person's response to your work that isn't what you wanted it to be is an extraordinarily rigid and controlling notion.
And I think
You know, I mean, I know.
Somebody called me a couple weeks ago and said this was the worst book ever published.
You were called on the phone?
Jonathan Yard, Washington Post, called me.
This was in a review?

a piece about this book this book has been reviewed before it's even written you know um just for the the sheer gall that some people suppose up to death and writing it off and presuming to um to tell my story you know it does come out coincidentally
at the same time that Paul Perreault's book is out on the U.S.
Nightfall.
And, you know, Paul... I haven't read that before.

He can cite, you know, and it's really kind of funny to me because the thing that he says, persuading him to do this book, is when he picked up a catalog and saw the two books that he had inscribed, he sent him out, Paul being offered for sale by a red book.
It's funny, because I wrote a book about video mania.
I mean, that kind of thing.
And then we encountered him on the street in London, and finally that was it.
Paul said, just take him to a chin and move on.
That was what he said.
Paul determined at that moment, so he says, to write the book.
Do you have such an epiphanous moment, I guess?
At what point did you decide it was time to write about your Salinger experience?
Well, I don't.
I don't regard mine as, it's similar to Paul DeRuze, but I have one.
Mine was the experience of seeing my daughter turn the age that I was when I got that first daughter from J.D.
Sand.
Revisiting this experience that I had tried so hard to put away and not deal with.
out of this sense of, I now think, misplaced obligation.
I tried very hard to be a good girl for a lot of years.
The one who would preserve and protect him at the expense of myself in many ways.

And when Audrey was turned, when I could suddenly look at my daughter, you know, about whom I'm a lot quicker to feel protectively than I may about my own self, I asked myself, well, my God, here have I been experiencing extreme long-term
of a relationship with a man who I'm protecting and he never... I'm continuing to sort of honor his wishes for me and he protected me never.
Do you think in retrospect you were an interlude for him and not much more?
That sounds a little complicated.
I think, I choose to believe, but I did, I'd like to think, you know, he did think I was a good writer.
He said extraordinary things about my writing, but I'd like to think that he
He recognized a writing voice that interested him.
But it is hard for me to believe now that that would have been sufficient for him to seek me out had my photograph in the New York Times been other than it was.
That's what's amazing, I guess, is that he really
It was suited.
It wasn't an occasional meeting.
I mean, I was very deliberate.
You can make an attempt.
But attempt?
She took steps to contract you, and then she succeeded.
And of course, you know, this is a man who knew very well that he wielded extraordinary power with his parents.
And his words had made generations of young people
and worship him.
So it was a pretty heady experience getting letters from that voice, that Holden Caulfield voice, speaking to me and telling me what a wonderful girl I was.
And I think you indicated that you hadn't read him prior to that, right?
No, no.
Again, you were 18 years old?
Mm-hmm.
I was 18.
He was a virgin.
I had 17, 15-year-old daughters.
If my older daughter would receive a letter like this, I wouldn't.
I can assure you.
Of course.
And you know the story.
If you have teenagers, you know the story.
You don't.
By the time they're that age, you do not control them.
But if you've done your job when they were younger, it may be a moot point.
And that's what my daughter says.
You know, if somebody asks her, you know, what would your mother do if Willip Rock invited you away?
There's no comparable person.
And...
or if you were going away with Philip Rock, and she said, it wouldn't happen.
And I believe that's so, that a fundamental component of this story was the
who I was when I met him, where I came from.
When I was a girl, she had been raised in a very troubled household, a fascinating, exciting, deeply inspiring one.
You don't call it dysfunctional.
I just avoid that word, it's so overused.
And I think it's sort of too easy to use it that way.
And I have been raised to please.
And I was looking desperately for something larger than myself, something outside of me to attach myself to, to make me feel worthy.
I was a person who found a sense of herself in gaining the approval of others.
And my daughter, I believe, is a person who has sufficient sense of herself that she's not going to give herself away to any man to win his love.
Somebody will have to love her the way she is.
They won't succeed in getting her to stick around if they want to change it.
Do you wish that your parents had...
I just find regret pretty futile emotion, sure.
I mean, I could wish for lots of things.
I could wish that my father didn't drink.
I could wish that my mother had been given the job that she so richly deserved.
And then I would be a different person.
And I like the person I am and where I am.
So I don't start in the cuts.
It was very unwise.
It was very unwise.
And I forgive them, you know.
I think this is a book about forgiveness, actually.
I think it's a book about recognizing the possibility that people that you love, people who did not ever set out to hurt you, but hurt you anyway,
and, um, are to be understood and forgiven.
You know, I tell some pretty dark tales of my parents, and I adore my own, and I'm able to tell those stories because ultimately, um, I love them and forgive them, and I think any real life
And then true love comes out of knowledge of the loved person, not from an illusion about who they are and detecting the horrible possibility that somebody might find out who they are.
My parents were brilliant, funny, interesting.
lovable, impossible, unwise, sometimes neglectful, sometimes, you know, over-involved, people who gave me great gifts.
I'd say some of the same things about J.L.
Sanger, although I feel less, you know, I don't feel devotion and affection for him, but I feel compassion, and I don't believe he set out to help me.
I feel that about every character in this book, and I don't think the memoir works if you write out of a different spirit.
If you're still in the I'll get back at him mode, I think that's a lousy book.
You know, maybe some people think that this one is, but I don't think anybody wants to read that.
So, how did the response bring to what you've seen?
It's not news to you that this book has gotten some very rabid criticism, but it's gotten some extraordinary response, too.
My website, which was at about 1,000 hits a day, was up to 40,000 hits a day.

Except when there have been two occasions in all the time of the website that I shut somebody out of the website, not because they were criticizing me, but because they were really being abusive to other people on the website.
But the response, you can see for yourself, it's overwhelmingly supportive, isn't it?
I mean, people are really grateful for this book.
Women in particular are grateful for this book.
And how's the book doing?
It's doing pretty early, though.
I don't even ask anymore because maybe you can appreciate it.
I've learned.
I don't tell you the real numbers anyway.
I don't even ask.
I know they're going back to press.
You know, if it was a number that I didn't like, I wouldn't want to know.
So I just figured, oh, I'll find out soon enough.
I can tell you, I've never had this big turn as a reading as I have.
So what do you read?
I'm just curious.
Do I read out loud?
Yeah.
I read.
What I like press to do always is to answer questions from top people.
So I try to.
I keep the reading portion short enough that I've got lots of room for it.
You know, in many ways, I am as opposite a person in my mode of operating as a writer as you could find, J.D.
Salinger.
I love readers.
I love to connect with readers.
It's why I have a website and why I had a newsletter before that.
J.D.
Salinger warned me in his first letter to me and forever after in our relationship, you know, to...
To seal myself away from the world and to never listen to publishers, readers in particular, that the mail was a dangerous thing that people would set out to exploit me.
Well, if somebody exploited me, it wasn't the readers.
And the letter that probably was more dangerous than any other letter I received was the letter from him, you know, my catcher in the rye, who was writing to rescue me.
And of course, unfortunately, you can't quote that letter.
There is a J.D.
Salinger syndrome out there, you know.
I felt it as recently as this morning.
How so?
Well, the paperback of my Dikey Island's Bible is coming out in spring, and I'm writing a new preface to explain, to bring, it's a non-tipsed book.
About what?
There's a book about bibliomania and stuff.
General Madness is still in friendship very well as a finalist in the national book page in 2005.
And it's been in height for three and a half years.
Oh, wow.
Wow.
That's incredible.
Just you and Midnight in the Garden of Eden.
Well, yeah.
Put a couple zeroes out there.
John Gray, he's the one that hasn't had any.
Yeah.
But it's been very gratifying.
It has been.
Because the first print was like $6,000, which nobody expected to do.
That was the number.
And we're up to $60,000.
Wow.
Great.
Since we're a $35 book, that's pretty good.
There's a lot of money for the book.
Anyway, anyway.
I have to bring things up to date.
I have a fellow.
I wrote a chapter about the book, Pete.
The guy who stole $20 million worth of the world.
So I don't remember that story all over America.
And we corresponded while he was in prison.
I just read about the book, Madness, through 25 centuries.
Yeah, it's a fun day.
Anyway, the guy writes me letters.
letters from prison, and I want to use them because he's been arrested again.
He's now going back to prison, and I want to report this, you know.
And so I'm talking to my editor today, Holt, and he says, Nick, you can't use it.
I said, Nick, I can't use it.
I said, he's in prison for Christ's sake.
And he's got ability, how am I going to?
He says, he still has a right to see you and see Jesus ever since he fell, you think.
Unless you can get a letter from him, give him your permission to use that letter, and he's not talking to anybody these days.
He's just not talking to us as well.
Forget it, I'll just paraphrase it.
Listen, just paraphrase it.
Even paraphrasing, you know, you have to be a little bit careful that the decision, the founder's decision, extends to paraphrasing.
We were tapping to one of the national experts on this case.
Is that right?
embarked on this telling of this tale.
I mean, the first obstacles were the emotional ones, the fear of sound and wrath.
Which is tangible and palpable and absolutely real.
And the fear of the wrath of all the opinion givers who are now passing judgment on me.
And then there was just the challenge, the writer's challenge of
how to tell the story of a seduction by words without being able to quote the words.
That was a new one for me.
I've written a lot of stuff.
And at first, it did seem, I think, partly because I still had this very reverential attitude towards his language.
Not unsounded.
I mean, he's not news to you.
He's an extraordinary writer.
Those letters.
seemed, had been so important in my life.
You know, those pages had meant so much to me.
But I couldn't imagine how I could tell the story without them.
And then, knowing I could not, I had to do a different thing, which was to convey what it felt like to receive them.
And to bring the story back to me.
And...
Not to turn it over to J.D.
Salinger.
It's not J.D.
Salinger's story.
It's my story.
And I'm actually now, you know, a week before this book went to press, it's about law had somehow been repealed, you know, overturned.
And they said to me... There are some phrases that I would have loved to have shared with people, you know, that were just so Salinger-like.
But ultimately, I no longer felt a particular need for them.
And partly that is because I...
I was forced to dig deeper into my own experience in ways that I might not have done if I hadn't had that.
And also because an extraordinary thing happened while I was writing this book that his spoken voice really returned to me.
And when I find myself, I mean I know, you know, people kind of, you know, take this issue with how on earth I could remember conversations.
Fair enough, and I never pretend, and I say very clearly enough that these are not, you know, rebate and a transfer to conversations.
I did not take notes, I did not keep journals, I did not have a little machine like this going.
I never supposed that I would ever write about him, so I wasn't, you know, just sneaking around to write it down.
It wasn't that that has made it possible for me to remember the way I do.
I remember the way I do because it was such a memorable voice.
It was, you know, it was the voice for me.
It was the most important voice.
And it happens that I was, and anybody who's crazy enough to
Excuse me to dig through all my years of writing and we'll kind of see this.
I remember what people say.
I remember what my children have said.
There have been less significant people in the eyes of some readers.
I happen to have an ear for those things.
What people say is very important to me.

The way some people remember, you know, I could ride in your car for a week and not remember what you were driving, but I'll remember what you say if it changed my life, if it hadn't accepted our needs, and his work did.
So, while I don't pretend that this is, you know, word for word what Jerry Sallinger said... Well, if you give us a disclaimer, so I think you can...
I will stand by the authenticity of the voice that I can say.
And the best truth is, you know, if you're a sound, you read her.
If it sounds like him or if it doesn't, it's a hard voice to...
He manufactured.
The only person I've ever known who spoke that way was him.
That first letter from Salinger, what do you suppose you're like?
It feels like another fetal pursuit.
Even if you didn't answer the letter, it didn't go up there.
It would have been impossible not to answer the letter, being who I was at that moment.
And what might my life have been?
Especially on the strength of the premise of the article, too.
I mean, because it did appeal to the premise of the article, didn't it?
His letter to you.

Oh, and, you know, for somebody to tell you, and for somebody so important and so powerful to tell you, you and I are soulmates, that's, you know, that's, that'll go further than, you know, a dozen roses, you know, a diamond necklace.
It's just you and me against the rest of the world.
And that word, lancement, more than anything else, had the effect of pulling me straight to his door.
I get the question.
What you think was... How I would have lived my life?
Do you think you've been a writer?
How many books now?
Five books?
Six books.
Eight if you count children's books.
I do not know.
I'll tell you one thing.
I would have finished college.
And if I have one regret, if I have one regret about the whole thing, it is that.
And not because, you know, somebody I read an article for of the courses was your degree.
Obviously not.
But I...

I forfeited my growing up years, that period of years that's sort of unique to that time when a young person finds out who she is and develops herself and gets to be young and to not have all the answers.
From the moment that I went off with Jared Soundra, I was really never young again.
I mean, it was a year.
You could have gone back to school.
Impossible to conceive of after that year.
Impossible to conceive of.
It was so, you know, I'd like to think if I did my job right, you'd sort of see that reading this book.
You know, it would be like taking somebody from, you know, the mountains of Tibet.
I don't know what you're saying.
Okay, all right.
But the point is, I'm just trying to make you understand.
All right.
By the time he sent me away and told me that he no longer approved of me, I had come to believe that he was the only person on the planet who understood the way life was supposed to be.
I really did.
And I couldn't be with the only person.
So where could I be?
Nowhere.
And a part of, you know, a crucial component to that time that I spent with him was he's telling me all the other people that I must not trust and believe in.
And that included, you know, my parents, publishers, editors, doctors, therapists, young people, old people, writers, not writers, and the human rights.
When you look back at that essay in the New York Times, and you read it,
How often?
I hadn't looked at it for over 20 years until I wrote this book.
How do you feel?
Are you struck by naivete?
So many people have criticized me for that piece, but I'm disinclined to help them out.
But of course, it was a very presumptuous thing to do that I would never now do, you know, to set out to explain my generation, to speak for all young people.
I don't think anybody has anything to do.
And at the same time that I say that, you know, I was young, you know, what was everybody else doing when they were 18?
You know, not necessarily the same things that they do now.
I was trying the best I knew how to do the job that I had been raised to do.
To bring honor and reward to the feet of my parents when they had eluded me.
I set out to
I didn't have a burning ambition to be a writer, actually, but I did have a burning ambition to achieve success wherever I could find it.
And I don't think it was actually some, it was not some sort of, you know, kind of need to see my name in lights for me.
I felt a big responsibility for my friends.
For them to see my name in lights.
For them to...
to have their own lives.
They both deserve so much more than they have felt, and they have put so much into me.
I think that's one of the dangers of having poor undue energy into their children.
I'm a big believer.
You can't love your children too much, and you can't
You can't give them too much sense that they're wonderful and you adore them, but I was raised to achieve.
Have you achieved to your satisfaction?
I have a different standard of achievement.
I'm very comfortable with what I've done with my not yet completed life.
My chief goal was to
was to make a happy family, to be part of a happy family.
And I thought for years, and that's a big part of the story that I tell, that the way to do it was to sort of make everything perfect for everybody.
And I made this picture of a happy family that was very stressful for all concerned.
Me, my children, my children's father.
I'm enormously proud of our children and who they are that's totally on their own.
that they created and the part that I played in shepherding them along.
And I'm proud of the work I've done.
But I'm not looking to win some big prize anymore.
If my definition of success was getting a pat on the back from Jonathan Yardley, I guess I'd be feeling pretty bad right now.
But it's not.
